data.name: PInvokesShouldNotBeVisibleTitle
data.value: P/Invokes should not be visible

data.name: PInvokesShouldNotBeVisibleDescription
data.value: A public or protected method in a public type has the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute (also implemented by the Declare keyword in Visual Basic). Such methods should not be exposed.

data.name: PInvokesShouldNotBeVisibleMessage
data.value: P/Invoke method '{0}' should not be visible

data.name: PInvokeDeclarationsShouldBePortableTitle
data.value: PInvoke declarations should be portable

data.name: PInvokeDeclarationsShouldBePortableDescription
data.value: This rule evaluates the size of each parameter and the return value of a P/Invoke, and verifies that the size of the parameter is correct when marshaled to unmanaged code on 32-bit and 64-bit operating systems.

data.name: PInvokeDeclarationsShouldBePortableMessageParameter
data.value: As it is declared in your code, parameter {0} of P/Invoke {1} will be {2} bytes wide on {3} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {4} bytes wide on {3} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {5}.

data.name: PInvokeDeclarationsShouldBePortableMessageReturn
data.value: As it is declared in your code, the return type of P/Invoke {0} will be {1} bytes wide on {2} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {3} bytes wide on {2} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {4}.

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsTitle
data.value: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsDescription
data.value: A platform invoke member allows partially trusted callers, has a string parameter, and does not explicitly marshal the string. This can cause a potential security vulnerability.

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsMessageParameter
data.value: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsMessageField
data.value: To reduce security risk, marshal field {0} as Unicode, by setting StructLayout.CharSet on {1} to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the field as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, use the BestFitMapping attribute to turn best-fit mapping off, and for added security, ensure ThrowOnUnmappableChar is on.

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsMessageParameterImplicitAnsi
data.value: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

data.name: SpecifyMarshalingForPInvokeStringArgumentsMessageFieldImplicitAnsi
data.value: To reduce security risk, marshal field {0} as Unicode, by setting StructLayout.CharSet on {1} to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the field as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, use the BestFitMapping attribute to turn best-fit mapping off, and for added security, to turn ThrowOnUnmappableChar on.

data.value: Use managed equivalents of win32 api

data.name: UseManagedEquivalentsOfWin32ApiDescription
data.value: An operating system invoke method is defined and a method that has the equivalent functionality is located in the .NET Framework class library.

data.name: UseManagedEquivalentsOfWin32ApiMessage
data.value: Use managed equivalents of win32 api

data.name: MarkBooleanPInvokeArgumentsWithMarshalAsTitle
data.value: Mark boolean PInvoke arguments with MarshalAs

data.name: MarkBooleanPInvokeArgumentsWithMarshalAsDescription
data.value: The Boolean data type has multiple representations in unmanaged code.

data.name: MarkBooleanPInvokeArgumentsWithMarshalAsMessageDefault
data.value: Add the MarshalAsAttribute to parameter {0} of P/Invoke {1}. If the corresponding unmanaged parameter is a 4-byte Win32 'BOOL', use [MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.Bool)]. For a 1-byte C++ 'bool', use MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.U1).

data.name: MarkBooleanPInvokeArgumentsWithMarshalAsMessageReturn
data.value: Add the MarshalAsAttribute to the return type of P/Invoke {0}. If the corresponding unmanaged return type is a 4-byte Win32 'BOOL', use MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.Bool). For a 1-byte C++ 'bool', use MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.U1).

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithNeutralResourcesLanguageTitle
data.value: Mark assemblies with NeutralResourcesLanguageAttribute

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithNeutralResourcesLanguageDescription
data.value: The NeutralResourcesLanguage attribute informs the ResourceManager of the language that was used to display the resources of a neutral culture for an assembly. This improves lookup performance for the first resource that you load and can reduce your working set.

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithNeutralResourcesLanguageMessage
data.value: Mark assemblies with NeutralResourcesLanguageAttribute

data.name: UseOrdinalStringComparisonTitle
data.value: Use ordinal string comparison

data.name: UseOrdinalStringComparisonDescription
data.value: A string comparison operation that is nonlinguistic does not set the StringComparison parameter to either Ordinal or OrdinalIgnoreCase. By explicitly setting the parameter to either StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase, your code often gains speed, becomes more correct, and becomes more reliable.

data.name: UseOrdinalStringComparisonMessageStringComparison
data.value: {0} passes '{1}' as the 'StringComparison' parameter to {2}. To perform a non-linguistic comparison, specify 'StringComparison.Ordinal' or 'StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase' instead.

data.name: UseOrdinalStringComparisonMessageStringComparer
data.value: {0} passes '{1}' as the 'StringComparer' parameter to {2}. To perform a non-linguistic comparison, specify 'StringComparer.Ordinal' or 'StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase' instead.

data.name: DoNotUseCountWhenAnyCanBeUsedDescription
data.value: For non-empty collections, Count() and LongCount() enumerate the entire sequence, while Any() stops at the first item or the first item that satisfies a condition.

data.name: DoNotUseCountWhenAnyCanBeUsedMessage
data.value: {0}() is used where Any() could be used instead to improve performance

data.name: DoNotUseCountWhenAnyCanBeUsedTitle
data.value: Do not use Count() or LongCount() when Any() can be used

data.name: DoNotUseTimersThatPreventPowerStateChangesTitle
data.value: Do not use timers that prevent power state changes

data.name: DoNotUseTimersThatPreventPowerStateChangesDescription
data.value: Higher-frequency periodic activity will keep the CPU busy and interfere with power-saving idle timers that turn off the display and hard disks.

data.name: DoNotUseTimersThatPreventPowerStateChangesMessage
data.value: Do not use timers that prevent power state changes

data.name: AvoidUnsealedAttributesTitle
data.value: Avoid unsealed attributes

data.name: AvoidUnsealedAttributesDescription
data.value: The .NET Framework class library provides methods for retrieving custom attributes. By default, these methods search the attribute inheritance hierarchy. Sealing the attribute eliminates the search through the inheritance hierarchy and can improve performance.

data.name: AvoidUnsealedAttributesMessage
data.value: Avoid unsealed attributes

data.name: TestForEmptyStringsUsingStringLengthTitle
data.value: Test for empty strings using string length

data.name: TestForEmptyStringsUsingStringLengthDescription
data.value: Comparing strings by using the String.Length property or the String.IsNullOrEmpty method is significantly faster than using Equals.

data.name: TestForEmptyStringsUsingStringLengthMessage
data.value: Test for empty strings using 'string.Length' property or 'string.IsNullOrEmpty' method instead of an Equality check

data.name: DoNotLockOnObjectsWithWeakIdentityTitle
data.value: Do not lock on objects with weak identity

data.name: DoNotLockOnObjectsWithWeakIdentityDescription
data.value: An object is said to have a weak identity when it can be directly accessed across application domain boundaries. A thread that tries to acquire a lock on an object that has a weak identity can be blocked by a second thread in a different application domain that has a lock on the same object.

data.name: DoNotLockOnObjectsWithWeakIdentityMessage
data.value: Do not lock on objects with weak identity

data.name: DoNotCatchCorruptedStateExceptionsInGeneralHandlersTitle
data.value: Do not catch corrupted state exceptions in general handlers.

data.name: DoNotCatchCorruptedStateExceptionsInGeneralHandlersDescription
data.value: Do not author general catch handlers in code that receives corrupted state exceptions.

data.name: DoNotCatchCorruptedStateExceptionsInGeneralHandlersMessage
data.value: Do not catch corrupted state exceptions in general handlers.

data.name: RethrowToPreserveStackDetailsTitle
data.value: Rethrow to preserve stack details

data.name: RethrowToPreserveStackDetailsDescription
data.value: An exception is rethrown and the exception is explicitly specified in the throw statement. If an exception is rethrown by specifying the exception in the throw statement, the list of method calls between the original method that threw the exception and the current method is lost.

data.name: RethrowToPreserveStackDetailsMessage
data.value: Rethrow to preserve stack details

data.name: DoNotRaiseReservedExceptionTypesTitle
data.value: Do not raise reserved exception types

data.name: DoNotRaiseReservedExceptionTypesDescription
data.value: An exception of type that is not sufficiently specific or reserved by the runtime should never be raised by user code. This makes the original error difficult to detect and debug. If this exception instance might be thrown, use a different exception type.

data.name: DoNotRaiseReservedExceptionTypesMessageTooGeneric
data.value: Exception type {0} is not sufficiently specific

data.name: DoNotRaiseReservedExceptionTypesMessageReserved
data.value: Exception type {0} is reserved by the runtime

data.value: Initialize value type static fields inline

data.name: InitializeReferenceTypeStaticFieldsInlineTitle
data.value: Initialize reference type static fields inline

data.name: InitializeReferenceTypeStaticFieldsInlineDescription

data.name: InitializeStaticFieldsInlineMessage
data.value: Initialize all static fields in '{0}' when those fields are declared and remove the explicit static constructor

data.name: DoNotCallOverridableMethodsInConstructorsTitle
data.value: Do not call overridable methods in constructors

data.name: DoNotCallOverridableMethodsInConstructorsDescription

data.name: DoNotCallOverridableMethodsInConstructorsMessage
data.value: Do not call overridable methods in constructors

data.name: DisposableTypesShouldDeclareFinalizerTitle
data.value: Disposable types should declare finalizer

data.name: DisposableTypesShouldDeclareFinalizerDescription

data.name: DisposableTypesShouldDeclareFinalizerMessage

data.name: FinalizersShouldCallBaseClassFinalizerMessage
data.value: Finalizers should call base class finalizer

data.name: SpecifyCultureInfoTitle
data.value: Specify CultureInfo

data.name: SpecifyCultureInfoDescription
data.value: A method or constructor calls a member that has an overload that accepts a System.Globalization.CultureInfo parameter, and the method or constructor does not call the overload that takes the CultureInfo parameter. When a CultureInfo or System.IFormatProvider object is not supplied, the default value that is supplied by the overloaded member might not have the effect that you want in all locales. If the result will be displayed to the user, specify 'CultureInfo.CurrentCulture' as the 'CultureInfo' parameter. Otherwise, if the result will be stored and accessed by software, such as when it is persisted to disk or to a database, specify 'CultureInfo.InvariantCulture'.

data.name: SpecifyCultureInfoMessage
data.value: The behavior of '{0}' could vary based on the current user's locale settings. Replace this call in '{1}' with a call to '{2}'.

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderTitle
data.value: Specify IFormatProvider

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderDescription
data.value: A method or constructor calls one or more members that have overloads that accept a System.IFormatProvider parameter, and the method or constructor does not call the overload that takes the IFormatProvider parameter. When a System.Globalization.CultureInfo or IFormatProvider object is not supplied, the default value that is supplied by the overloaded member might not have the effect that you want in all locales. If the result will be based on the input from/output displayed to the user, specify 'CultureInfo.CurrentCulture' as the 'IFormatProvider'. Otherwise, if the result will be stored and accessed by software, such as when it is loaded from disk/database and when it is persisted to disk/database, specify 'CultureInfo.InvariantCulture'.

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderMessageIFormatProviderAlternateString
data.value: The behavior of '{0}' could vary based on the current user's locale settings. Replace this call in '{1}' with a call to '{2}'.

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderMessageIFormatProviderAlternate
data.value: The behavior of '{0}' could vary based on the current user's locale settings. Replace this call in '{1}' with a call to '{2}'.

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderMessageUICultureString
data.value: '{0}' passes '{1}' as the 'IFormatProvider' parameter to '{2}'. This property returns a culture that is inappropriate for formatting methods.

data.name: SpecifyIFormatProviderMessageUICulture
data.value: '{0}' passes '{1}' as the 'IFormatProvider' parameter to '{2}'. This property returns a culture that is inappropriate for formatting methods.

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1307Title
data.value: Specify StringComparison for clarity

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1307Description
data.value: A string comparison operation uses a method overload that does not set a StringComparison parameter. It is recommended to use the overload with StringComparison parameter for clarity of intent. If the result will be displayed to the user, such as when sorting a list of items for display in a list box, specify 'StringComparison.CurrentCulture' or 'StringComparison.CurrentCultureIgnoreCase' as the 'StringComparison' parameter. If comparing case-insensitive identifiers, such as file paths, environment variables, or registry keys and values, specify 'StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase'. Otherwise, if comparing case-sensitive identifiers, specify 'StringComparison.Ordinal'.

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1307Message
data.value: '{0}' has a method overload that takes a 'StringComparison' parameter. Replace this call in '{1}' with a call to '{2}' for clarity of intent.

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1310Title
data.value: Specify StringComparison for correctness

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1310Description
data.value: A string comparison operation uses a method overload that does not set a StringComparison parameter, hence its behavior could vary based on the current user's locale settings. It is strongly recommended to use the overload with StringComparison parameter for correctness and clarity of intent. If the result will be displayed to the user, such as when sorting a list of items for display in a list box, specify 'StringComparison.CurrentCulture' or 'StringComparison.CurrentCultureIgnoreCase' as the 'StringComparison' parameter. If comparing case-insensitive identifiers, such as file paths, environment variables, or registry keys and values, specify 'StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase'. Otherwise, if comparing case-sensitive identifiers, specify 'StringComparison.Ordinal'.

data.name: SpecifyStringComparisonCA1310Message
data.value: The behavior of '{0}' could vary based on the current user's locale settings. Replace this call in '{1}' with a call to '{2}'.

data.name: NormalizeStringsToUppercaseTitle
data.value: Normalize strings to uppercase

data.name: NormalizeStringsToUppercaseDescription
data.value: Strings should be normalized to uppercase. A small group of characters cannot make a round trip when they are converted to lowercase. To make a round trip means to convert the characters from one locale to another locale that represents character data differently, and then to accurately retrieve the original characters from the converted characters.

data.name: NormalizeStringsToUppercaseMessageToUpper
data.value: In method '{0}', replace the call to '{1}' with '{2}'

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyTitle
data.value: Dispose methods should call SuppressFinalize

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyDescription
data.value: A method that is an implementation of Dispose does not call GC.SuppressFinalize; or a method that is not an implementation of Dispose calls GC.SuppressFinalize; or a method calls GC.SuppressFinalize and passes something other than this (Me in Visual Basic).

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyMessageNotCalledWithFinalizer
data.value: Change {0} to call {1}. This will prevent unnecessary finalization of the object once it has been disposed and it has fallen out of scope.

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyMessageNotCalled
data.value: Change {0} to call {1}. This will prevent derived types that introduce a finalizer from needing to re-implement 'IDisposable' to call it.

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyMessageNotPassedThis
data.value: {0} calls {1} on something other than itself. Change the call site to pass 'this' ('Me' in Visual Basic) instead.

data.name: CallGCSuppressFinalizeCorrectlyMessageOutsideDispose
data.value: {0} calls {1}, a method that is typically only called within an implementation of 'IDisposable.Dispose'. Refer to the IDisposable pattern for more information.

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyTitle
data.value: Instantiate argument exceptions correctly

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyDescription
data.value: A call is made to the default (parameterless) constructor of an exception type that is or derives from ArgumentException, or an incorrect string argument is passed to a parameterized constructor of an exception type that is or derives from ArgumentException.

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyMessageNoArguments
data.value: Call the {0} constructor that contains a message and/or paramName parameter

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyMessageIncorrectMessage
data.value: Method {0} passes parameter name '{1}' as the {2} argument to a {3} constructor. Replace this argument with a descriptive message and pass the parameter name in the correct position.

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyMessageIncorrectParameterName
data.value: Method {0} passes '{1}' as the {2} argument to a {3} constructor. Replace this argument with one of the method's parameter names. Note that the provided parameter name should have the exact casing as declared on the method.

data.name: UseArrayEmpty
data.value: Use Array.Empty

data.name: UseIndexer
data.value: Use indexer

data.name: DisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposedDescription
data.value: A type that implements System.IDisposable declares fields that are of types that also implement IDisposable. The Dispose method of the field is not called by the Dispose method of the declaring type. To fix a violation of this rule, call Dispose on fields that are of types that implement IDisposable if you are responsible for allocating and releasing the unmanaged resources held by the field.

data.name: DisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposedMessage
data.value: '{0}' contains field '{1}' that is of IDisposable type '{2}', but it is never disposed. Change the Dispose method on '{0}' to call Close or Dispose on this field.

data.name: DisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposedTitle
data.value: Disposable fields should be disposed

data.name: DisposeMethodsShouldCallBaseClassDisposeDescription
data.value: A type that implements System.IDisposable inherits from a type that also implements IDisposable. The Dispose method of the inheriting type does not call the Dispose method of the parent type. To fix a violation of this rule, call base.Dispose in your Dispose method.

data.name: DisposeMethodsShouldCallBaseClassDisposeMessage
data.value: Ensure that method '{0}' calls '{1}' in all possible control flow paths

data.name: DisposeMethodsShouldCallBaseClassDisposeTitle
data.value: Dispose methods should call base class dispose

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeDescription
data.value: If a disposable object is not explicitly disposed before all references to it are out of scope, the object will be disposed at some indeterminate time when the garbage collector runs the finalizer of the object. Because an exceptional event might occur that will prevent the finalizer of the object from running, the object should be explicitly disposed instead.

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeNotDisposedMessage
data.value: Call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object created by '{0}' before all references to it are out of scope

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeMayBeDisposedMessage
data.value: Use recommended dispose pattern to ensure that object created by '{0}' is disposed on all paths. If possible, wrap the creation within a 'using' statement or a 'using' declaration. Otherwise, use a try-finally pattern, with a dedicated local variable declared before the try region and an unconditional Dispose invocation on non-null value in the 'finally' region, say 'x?.Dispose()'. If the object is explicitly disposed within the try region or the dispose ownership is transfered to another object or method, assign 'null' to the local variable just after such an operation to prevent double dispose in 'finally'.

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeNotDisposedOnExceptionPathsMessage
data.value: Object created by '{0}' is not disposed along all exception paths. Call System.IDisposable.Dispose on the object before all references to it are out of scope.

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeMayBeDisposedOnExceptionPathsMessage
data.value: Use recommended dispose pattern to ensure that object created by '{0}' is disposed on all exception paths. If possible, wrap the creation within a 'using' statement or a 'using' declaration. Otherwise, use a try-finally pattern, with a dedicated local variable declared before the try region and an unconditional Dispose invocation on non-null value in the 'finally' region, say 'x?.Dispose()'. If the object is explicitly disposed within the try region or the dispose ownership is transfered to another object or method, assign 'null' to the local variable just after such an operation to prevent double dispose in 'finally'.

data.name: DisposeObjectsBeforeLosingScopeTitle
data.value: Dispose objects before losing scope

data.name: DoNotAddSchemaByURLDescription
data.value: This overload of XmlSchemaCollection.Add method internally enables DTD processing on the XML reader instance used, and uses UrlResolver for resolving external XML entities. The outcome is information disclosure. Content from file system or network shares for the machine processing the XML can be exposed to attacker. In addition, an attacker can use this as a DoS vector.

data.name: DoNotCallDangerousMethodsInDeserialization
data.value: Do Not Call Dangerous Methods In Deserialization

data.name: DoNotCallDangerousMethodsInDeserializationDescription
data.value: Insecure Deserialization is a vulnerability which occurs when untrusted data is used to abuse the logic of an application, inflict a Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack, or even execute arbitrary code upon it being deserialized. It’s frequently possible for malicious users to abuse these deserialization features when the application is deserializing untrusted data which is under their control. Specifically, invoke dangerous methods in the process of deserialization. Successful insecure deserialization attacks could allow an attacker to carry out attacks such as DoS attacks, authentication bypasses, and remote code execution.

data.name: DoNotCallDangerousMethodsInDeserializationMessage
data.value: When deserializing an instance of class {0}, method {1} can call dangerous method {2}. The potential method invocations are: {3}.

data.name: DoNotDisableCertificateValidation
data.value: Do Not Disable Certificate Validation

data.name: DoNotDisableCertificateValidationDescription
data.value: A certificate can help authenticate the identity of the server. Clients should validate the server certificate to ensure requests are sent to the intended server. If the ServerCertificateValidationCallback always returns 'true', any certificate will pass validation.

data.name: DoNotDisableCertificateValidationMessage
data.value: The ServerCertificateValidationCallback is set to a function that accepts any server certificate, by always returning true. Ensure that server certificates are validated to verify the identity of the server receiving requests.

data.name: DoNotDisableHTTPHeaderChecking
data.value: Do Not Disable HTTP Header Checking

data.name: DoNotDisableHTTPHeaderCheckingDescription
data.value: HTTP header checking enables encoding of the carriage return and newline characters, \r and \n, that are found in response headers. This encoding can help to avoid injection attacks that exploit an application that echoes untrusted data contained by the header.

data.name: DoNotDisableHTTPHeaderCheckingMessage
data.value: Do not disable HTTP header checking

data.name: DoNotDisableRequestValidation
data.value: Do Not Disable Request Validation

data.name: DoNotDisableRequestValidationDescription
data.value: Request validation is a feature in ASP.NET that examines HTTP requests and determines whether they contain potentially dangerous content. This check adds protection from markup or code in the URL query string, cookies, or posted form values that might have been added for malicious purposes. So, it is generally desirable and should be left enabled for defense in depth.

data.name: DoNotDisableRequestValidationMessage
data.value: {0} has request validation disabled

data.name: DoNotDisableSchUseStrongCrypto

data.name: DoNotDisableSchUseStrongCryptoDescription
data.value: Starting with the .NET Framework 4.6, the System.Net.ServicePointManager and System.Net.Security.SslStream classes are recommended to use new protocols. The old ones have protocol weaknesses and are not supported. Setting Switch.System.Net.DontEnableSchUseStrongCrypto with true will use the old weak crypto check and opt out of the protocol migration.

data.name: DoNotDisableSchUseStrongCryptoMessage
data.value: {0} disables TLS 1.2 and enables SSLv3

data.name: DoNotInstallRootCertDescription
data.value: By default, the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store is configured with a set of public CAs that has met the requirements of the Microsoft Root Certificate Program. Since all trusted root CAs can issue certificates for any domain, an attacker can pick a weak or coercible CA that you install by yourself to target for an attack – and a single vulnerable, malicious or coercible CA undermines the security of the entire system. To make matters worse, these attacks can go unnoticed quite easily.

data.name: PotentialReferenceCycleInDeserializedObjectGraphTitle
data.value: Potential reference cycle in deserialized object graph

data.name: PotentialReferenceCycleInDeserializedObjectGraphDescription
data.value: Review code that processes untrusted deserialized data for handling of unexpected reference cycles. An unexpected reference cycle should not cause the code to enter an infinite loop. Otherwise, an unexpected reference cycle can allow an attacker to DOS or exhaust the memory of the process when deserializing untrusted data.

data.name: PotentialReferenceCycleInDeserializedObjectGraphMessage
data.value: {0} participates in a potential reference cycle

data.name: DoNotSerializeTypesWithPointerFields
data.value: Do Not Serialize Types With Pointer Fields

data.name: DoNotSerializeTypesWithPointerFieldsDescription
data.value: Pointers are not "type safe" in the sense that you cannot guarantee the correctness of the memory they point at. So, serializing types with pointer fields is dangerous, as it may allow an attacker to control the pointer.

data.name: DoNotSerializeTypesWithPointerFieldsMessage
data.value: Pointer field {0} on serializable type

data.name: DoNotUseAccountSAS
data.value: Do Not Use Account Shared Access Signature

data.name: DoNotUseAccountSASDescription
data.value: Shared Access Signatures(SAS) are a vital part of the security model for any application using Azure Storage, they should provide limited and safe permissions to your storage account to clients that don't have the account key. All of the operations available via a service SAS are also available via an account SAS, that is, account SAS is too powerful. So it is recommended to use Service SAS to delegate access more carefully.

data.name: DoNotUseAccountSASMessage
data.value: Use Service SAS instead of Account SAS for fine grained access control and container-level access policy

data.name: DoNotUseBrokenCryptographicAlgorithms
data.value: Do Not Use Broken Cryptographic Algorithms

data.name: DoNotUseBrokenCryptographicAlgorithmsDescription
data.value: An attack making it computationally feasible to break this algorithm exists. This allows attackers to break the cryptographic guarantees it is designed to provide. Depending on the type and application of this cryptographic algorithm, this may allow attackers to read enciphered messages, tamper with enciphered messages, forge digital signatures, tamper with hashed content, or otherwise compromise any cryptosystem based on this algorithm. Replace encryption uses with the AES algorithm (AES-256, AES-192 and AES-128 are acceptable) with a key length greater than or equal to 128 bits. Replace hashing uses with a hashing function in the SHA-2 family, such as SHA512, SHA384, or SHA256. Replace digital signature uses with RSA with a key length greater than or equal to 2048-bits, or ECDSA with a key length greater than or equal to 256 bits.

data.name: DoNotUseBrokenCryptographicAlgorithmsMessage
data.value: {0} uses a broken cryptographic algorithm {1}

data.name: DoNotUseDeprecatedSecurityProtocols
data.value: Do Not Use Deprecated Security Protocols

data.name: DoNotUseDeprecatedSecurityProtocolsDescription
data.value: Using a deprecated security protocol rather than the system default is risky.

data.name: DoNotUseDeprecatedSecurityProtocolsMessage
data.value: Hard-coded use of deprecated security protocol {0}

data.name: DoNotUseMD5

data.name: DoNotUseMD5Description
data.value: This type implements MD5, a cryptographically insecure hashing function. Hash collisions are computationally feasible for the MD5 and HMACMD5 algorithms. Replace this usage with a SHA-2 family hash algorithm (SHA512, SHA384, SHA256).

data.value: Password-based key derivation should use PBKDF2 with SHA-2. Avoid using PasswordDeriveBytes since it generates a PBKDF1 key. Avoid using Rfc2898DeriveBytes.CryptDeriveKey since it doesn't use the iteration count or salt.

data.name: DoNotUseSHA1Description
data.value: This type implements SHA1, a cryptographically insecure hashing function. Hash collisions are computationally feasible for the SHA-1 and SHA-0 algorithms. Replace this usage with a SHA-2 family hash algorithm (SHA512, SHA384, SHA256).

data.name: DoNotUseWeakCryptographicAlgorithms
data.value: Do Not Use Weak Cryptographic Algorithms

data.name: DoNotUseWeakCryptographicAlgorithmsDescription
data.value: Cryptographic algorithms degrade over time as attacks become for advances to attacker get access to more computation. Depending on the type and application of this cryptographic algorithm, further degradation of the cryptographic strength of it may allow attackers to read enciphered messages, tamper with enciphered messages, forge digital signatures, tamper with hashed content, or otherwise compromise any cryptosystem based on this algorithm. Replace encryption uses with the AES algorithm (AES-256, AES-192 and AES-128 are acceptable) with a key length greater than or equal to 128 bits. Replace hashing uses with a hashing function in the SHA-2 family, such as SHA-2 512, SHA-2 384, or SHA-2 256.

data.name: UseAsSpanInsteadOfArrayRangeIndexerDescription

data.name: DoNotAddArchiveItemPathToTheTargetFileSystemPathDescription
data.value: When extracting files from an archive and using the archive item's path, check if the path is safe. Archive path can be relative and can lead to file system access outside of the expected file system target path, leading to malicious config changes and remote code execution via lay-and-wait technique.

data.name: DoNotAddArchiveItemPathToTheTargetFileSystemPathMessage

data.name: DoNotCreateTasksWithoutPassingATaskSchedulerTitle
data.value: Do not create tasks without passing a TaskScheduler

data.name: DoNotCreateTasksWithoutPassingATaskSchedulerDescription
data.value: Do not create tasks unless you are using one of the overloads that takes a TaskScheduler. The default is to schedule on TaskScheduler.Current, which would lead to deadlocks. Either use TaskScheduler.Default to schedule on the thread pool, or explicitly pass TaskScheduler.Current to make your intentions clear.

data.name: DoNotCreateTasksWithoutPassingATaskSchedulerMessage
data.value: Do not create tasks without passing a TaskScheduler

data.name: DoNotDefineFinalizersForTypesDerivedFromMemoryManagerDescription
data.value: Adding a finalizer to a type derived from MemoryManager<T> may permit memory to be freed while it is still in use by a Span<T>.

data.name: DoNotDefineFinalizersForTypesDerivedFromMemoryManagerMessage
data.value: Adding a finalizer to a type derived from MemoryManager<T> may permit memory to be freed while it is still in use by a Span<T>

data.name: DoNotDefineFinalizersForTypesDerivedFromMemoryManagerTitle
data.value: Do not define finalizers for types derived from MemoryManager<T>

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyTitle
data.value: Use ValueTasks correctly

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyDescription
data.value: ValueTasks returned from member invocations are intended to be directly awaited. Attempts to consume a ValueTask multiple times or to directly access one's result before it's known to be completed may result in an exception or corruption. Ignoring such a ValueTask is likely an indication of a functional bug and may degrade performance.

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyMessage_General
data.value: ValueTask instances returned from method calls should be directly awaited, returned, or passed as an argument to another method call. Other usage, such as storing an instance into a local or a field, is likely an indication of a bug, as ValueTask instances must only ever be consumed once.

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyMessage_Unconsumed
data.value: ValueTask instances returned from method calls should always be used, typically awaited. Not doing so often represents a functional bug, but even if it doesn't, it can result in degraded performance if the target method pools objects for use with ValueTasks.

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyMessage_DoubleConsumption
data.value: ValueTask instances should only be consumed once, such as via an await. Consuming the same ValueTask instance multiple times can result in exceptions and data corruption.

data.name: UseValueTasksCorrectlyMessage_AccessingIncompleteResult
data.value: ValueTask instances should not have their result directly accessed unless the instance has already completed. Unlike Tasks, calling Result or GetAwaiter().GetResult() on a ValueTask is not guaranteed to block until the operation completes. If you can't simply await the instance, consider first checking its IsCompleted property (or asserting it's true if you know that to be the case).

data.name: DoNotCreateTaskCompletionSourceWithWrongArgumentsTitle
data.value: Argument passed to TaskCompletionSource constructor should be TaskCreationOptions enum instead of TaskContinuationOptions enum

data.name: DoNotCreateTaskCompletionSourceWithWrongArgumentsDescription
data.value: TaskCompletionSource has constructors that take TaskCreationOptions that control the underlying Task, and constructors that take object state that's stored in the task. Accidentally passing a TaskContinuationOptions instead of a TaskCreationOptions will result in the call treating the options as state.

data.name: DoNotCreateTaskCompletionSourceWithWrongArgumentsMessage
data.value: Argument contains TaskContinuationsOptions enum instead of TaskCreationOptions enum

data.name: DoNotCreateTaskCompletionSourceWithWrongArgumentsFix
data.value: Replace TaskContinuationOptions with TaskCreationOptions.

data.name: JsonNetInsecureSerializerMessage
data.value: When deserializing untrusted input, allowing arbitrary types to be deserialized is insecure. When using deserializing JsonSerializer, use TypeNameHandling.None, or for values other than None, restrict deserialized types with a SerializationBinder.

data.name: JsonNetInsecureSerializerTitle
data.value: Do not deserialize with JsonSerializer using an insecure configuration

data.name: JsonNetMaybeInsecureSerializerMessage
data.value: When deserializing untrusted input, allowing arbitrary types to be deserialized is insecure. When using deserializing JsonSerializer, use TypeNameHandling.None, or for values other than None, restrict deserialized types with a SerializationBinder.

data.name: JsonNetMaybeInsecureSerializerTitle
data.value: Ensure that JsonSerializer has a secure configuration when deserializing

data.name: UseDefaultDllImportSearchPathsAttribute
data.value: Use DefaultDllImportSearchPaths attribute for P/Invokes

data.name: UseDefaultDllImportSearchPathsAttributeDescription
data.value: By default, P/Invokes using DllImportAttribute probe a number of directories, including the current working directory for the library to load. This can be a security issue for certain applications, leading to DLL hijacking.

data.name: UseDefaultDllImportSearchPathsAttributeMessage
data.value: The method {0} didn't use DefaultDllImportSearchPaths attribute for P/Invokes.

data.name: DoNotUseUnsafeDllImportSearchPath
data.value: Do not use unsafe DllImportSearchPath value

data.name: DoNotUseUnsafeDllImportSearchPathDescription
data.value: There could be a malicious DLL in the default DLL search directories. Or, depending on where your application is run from, there could be a malicious DLL in the application's directory. Use a DllImportSearchPath value that specifies an explicit search path instead. The DllImportSearchPath flags that this rule looks for can be configured in .editorconfig.

data.name: DoNotUseUnsafeDllImportSearchPathMessage
data.value: Use of unsafe DllImportSearchPath value {0}

data.name: UseAutoValidateAntiforgeryToken
data.value: Use antiforgery tokens in ASP.NET Core MVC controllers

data.name: UseAutoValidateAntiforgeryTokenDescription
data.value: Handling a POST, PUT, PATCH, or DELETE request without validating an antiforgery token may be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery attacks. A cross-site request forgery attack can send malicious requests from an authenticated user to your ASP.NET Core MVC controller.

data.name: UseAutoValidateAntiforgeryTokenMessage
data.value: Method {0} handles a {1} request without performing antiforgery token validation. You also need to ensure that your HTML form sends an antiforgery token.

data.name: MissHttpVerbAttribute
data.value: Miss HttpVerb attribute for action methods

data.name: MissHttpVerbAttributeMessage
data.value: Action method {0} needs to specify the HTTP request kind explicitly

data.name: DoNotUseInsecureRandomness
data.value: Do not use insecure randomness

data.name: DoNotUseInsecureRandomnessMessage
data.value: {0} is an insecure random number generator. Use cryptographically secure random number generators when randomness is required for security.

data.name: DoNotUseInsecureRandomnessDescription
data.value: Using a cryptographically weak pseudo-random number generator may allow an attacker to predict what security-sensitive value will be generated. Use a cryptographically strong random number generator if an unpredictable value is required, or ensure that weak pseudo-random numbers aren't used in a security-sensitive manner.

data.name: DoNotUseCountAsyncWhenAnyAsyncCanBeUsedDescription
data.value: For non-empty collections, CountAsync() and LongCountAsync() enumerate the entire sequence, while AnyAsync() stops at the first item or the first item that satisfies a condition.

data.name: DoNotUseCountAsyncWhenAnyAsyncCanBeUsedMessage
data.value: {0}() is used where AnyAsync() could be used instead to improve performance

data.name: DoNotUseCountAsyncWhenAnyAsyncCanBeUsedTitle
data.value: Do not use CountAsync() or LongCountAsync() when AnyAsync() can be used

data.name: UsePropertyInsteadOfCountMethodWhenAvailableDescription
data.value: Enumerable.Count() potentially enumerates the sequence while a Length/Count property is a direct access.

data.name: UsePropertyInsteadOfCountMethodWhenAvailableMessage
data.value: Use the "{0}" property instead of Enumerable.Count()

data.name: UsePropertyInsteadOfCountMethodWhenAvailableTitle
data.value: Use Length/Count property instead of Count() when available

data.name: SetHttpOnlyForHttpCookie
data.value: Set HttpOnly to true for HttpCookie

data.name: SetHttpOnlyForHttpCookieDescription
data.value: As a defense in depth measure, ensure security sensitive HTTP cookies are marked as HttpOnly. This indicates web browsers should disallow scripts from accessing the cookies. Injected malicious scripts are a common way of stealing cookies.

data.name: SetHttpOnlyForHttpCookieMessage
data.value: HttpCookie.HttpOnly is set to false or not set at all when using an HttpCookie. Ensure security sensitive cookies are marked as HttpOnly to prevent malicious scripts from stealing the cookies

data.name: DeprecatedSslProtocolsDescription
data.value: Older protocol versions of Transport Layer Security (TLS) are less secure than TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3, and are more likely to have new vulnerabilities. Avoid older protocol versions to minimize risk.

data.name: DeprecatedSslProtocolsMessage
data.value: Transport Layer Security protocol version '{0}' is deprecated. Use 'None' to let the Operating System choose a version.

data.name: DeprecatedSslProtocolsTitle
data.value: Do not use deprecated SslProtocols values

data.name: HardcodedSslProtocolsDescription
data.value: Current Transport Layer Security protocol versions may become deprecated if vulnerabilities are found. Avoid hardcoding SslProtocols values to keep your application secure. Use 'None' to let the Operating System choose a version.

data.name: HardcodedSslProtocolsMessage
data.value: Avoid hardcoding SslProtocols '{0}' to ensure your application remains secure in the future. Use 'None' to let the Operating System choose a version.

data.name: HardcodedSslProtocolsTitle
data.value: Avoid hardcoded SslProtocols values

data.name: MissHttpVerbAttributeDescription
data.value: All the methods that create, edit, delete, or otherwise modify data do so in the [HttpPost] overload of the method, which needs to be protected with the anti forgery attribute from request forgery. Performing a GET operation should be a safe operation that has no side effects and doesn't modify your persisted data.

data.name: DefinitelyDisableHttpClientCRLCheck
data.value: HttpClients should enable certificate revocation list checks

data.name: DefinitelyDisableHttpClientCRLCheckMessage
data.value: HttpClient is created without enabling CheckCertificateRevocationList

data.name: DoNotDisableHttpClientCRLCheckDescription
data.value: Using HttpClient without providing a platform specific handler (WinHttpHandler or CurlHandler or HttpClientHandler) where the CheckCertificateRevocationList property is set to true, will allow revoked certificates to be accepted by the HttpClient as valid.

data.name: MaybeDisableHttpClientCRLCheck
data.value: Ensure HttpClient certificate revocation list check is not disabled

data.name: MaybeDisableHttpClientCRLCheckMessage
data.value: HttpClient may be created without enabling CheckCertificateRevocationList

data.name: DoNotHardCodeCertificate
data.value: Do not hard-code certificate

data.name: DoNotHardCodeCertificateDescription
data.value: Hard-coded certificates in source code are vulnerable to being exploited.

data.name: DoNotHardCodeCertificateMessage
data.value: Potential security vulnerability was found where '{0}' in method '{1}' may be tainted by hard-coded certificate from '{2}' in method '{3}'

data.name: DefinitelyUseCreateEncryptorWithNonDefaultIV
data.value: Do not use CreateEncryptor with non-default IV

data.name: DefinitelyUseCreateEncryptorWithNonDefaultIVMessage
data.value: Symmetric encryption uses non-default initialization vector, which could be potentially repeatable

data.name: MaybeUseCreateEncryptorWithNonDefaultIV
data.value: Use CreateEncryptor with the default IV

data.name: MaybeUseCreateEncryptorWithNonDefaultIVMessage
data.value: The non-default initialization vector, which can be potentially repeatable, is used in the encryption. Ensure use the default one.

data.name: DoNotUseCreateEncryptorWithNonDefaultIVDescription
data.value: Symmetric encryption should always use a non-repeatable initialization vector to prevent dictionary attacks.

data.value: When deserializing untrusted input, deserializing a {0} object is insecure. '{1}' either is or derives from {0}

data.value: Unsafe DataSet or DataTable in deserialized object graph can be vulnerable to remote code execution attacks

data.name: DoNotUseStackallocInLoopsTitle
data.value: Do not use stackalloc in loops

data.name: DoNotUseStackallocInLoopsDescription
data.value: Stack space allocated by a stackalloc is only released at the end of the current method's invocation. Using it in a loop can result in unbounded stack growth and eventual stack overflow conditions.

data.name: DoNotUseStackallocInLoopsMessage
data.value: Potential stack overflow. Move the stackalloc out of the loop.

data.name: PreferStreamAsyncMemoryOverloadsTitle
data.value: Prefer the 'Memory'-based overloads for 'ReadAsync' and 'WriteAsync'

data.name: PreferStreamAsyncMemoryOverloadsDescription
data.value: 'Stream' has a 'ReadAsync' overload that takes a 'Memory<Byte>' as the first argument, and a 'WriteAsync' overload that takes a 'ReadOnlyMemory<Byte>' as the first argument. Prefer calling the memory based overloads, which are more efficient.

data.name: PreferStreamAsyncMemoryOverloadsMessage
data.value: Change the '{0}' method call to use the '{1}' overload

data.name: ForwardCancellationTokenToInvocationsDescription
data.value: Forward the 'CancellationToken' parameter to methods to ensure the operation cancellation notifications gets properly propagated, or pass in 'CancellationToken.None' explicitly to indicate intentionally not propagating the token.

data.name: ForwardCancellationTokenToInvocationsMessage
data.value: Forward the '{0}' parameter to the '{1}' method or pass in 'CancellationToken.None' explicitly to indicate intentionally not propagating the token

data.name: ForwardCancellationTokenToInvocationsTitle
data.value: Forward the 'CancellationToken' parameter to methods

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyChangeToTwoArgumentCodeFixTitle
data.value: Change to call the two argument constructor, pass null for the message.

data.name: InstantiateArgumentExceptionsCorrectlyFlipArgumentOrderCodeFixTitle
data.value: Swap the arguments order

data.name: PreferTypedStringBuilderAppendOverloadsTitle
data.value: Prefer strongly-typed Append and Insert method overloads on StringBuilder

data.name: PreferTypedStringBuilderAppendOverloadsDescription
data.value: StringBuilder.Append and StringBuilder.Insert provide overloads for multiple types beyond System.String. When possible, prefer the strongly-typed overloads over using ToString() and the string-based overload.

data.name: PreferTypedStringBuilderAppendOverloadsMessage
data.value: Remove the ToString call in order to use a strongly-typed StringBuilder overload

data.name: PreferTypedStringBuilderAppendOverloadsRemoveToString
data.value: Remove the ToString call

data.name: PreferStringContainsOverIndexOfDescription
data.value: Calls to 'string.IndexOf' where the result is used to check for the presence/absence of a substring can be replaced by 'string.Contains'.

data.name: PreferStringContainsOverIndexOfMessage
data.value: Use 'string.Contains' instead of 'string.IndexOf' to improve readability

data.name: PreferStringContainsOverIndexOfTitle
data.value: Consider using 'string.Contains' instead of 'string.IndexOf'

data.name: PreferConstCharOverConstUnitStringInStringBuilderDescription
data.value: 'StringBuilder.Append(char)' is more efficient than 'StringBuilder.Append(string)' when the string is a single character. When calling 'Append' with a constant, prefer using a constant char rather than a constant string containing one character.

data.name: PreferConstCharOverConstUnitStringInStringBuilderMessage
data.value: Use 'StringBuilder.Append(char)' instead of 'StringBuilder.Append(string)' when the input is a constant unit string

data.name: PreferConstCharOverConstUnitStringInStringBuilderTitle
data.value: Consider using 'StringBuilder.Append(char)' when applicable

data.name: ProvideCorrectArgumentToEnumHasFlagDescription
data.value: 'Enum.HasFlag' method expects the 'enum' argument to be of the same 'enum' type as the instance on which the method is invoked and that this 'enum' is marked with 'System.FlagsAttribute'. If these are different 'enum' types, an unhandled exception will be thrown at runtime. If the 'enum' type is not marked with 'System.FlagsAttribute' the call will always return 'false' at runtime.

data.name: ProvideCorrectArgumentToEnumHasFlagMessageDifferentType
data.value: The argument type, '{0}', must be the same as the enum type '{1}'

data.name: ProvideCorrectArgumentToEnumHasFlagTitle
data.value: Provide correct 'enum' argument to 'Enum.HasFlag'

data.name: PreferIsEmptyOverCountDescription
data.value: For determining whether the object contains or not any items, prefer using 'IsEmpty' property rather than retrieving the number of items from the 'Count' property and comparing it to 0 or 1.

data.name: PreferIsEmptyOverCountMessage
data.value: Prefer 'IsEmpty' over 'Count' to determine whether the object is empty

data.name: PreferIsEmptyOverCountTitle
data.value: Prefer IsEmpty over Count

data.name: UseEnvironmentProcessIdDescription
data.value: 'Environment.ProcessId' is simpler and faster than 'Process.GetCurrentProcess().Id'.

data.name: UseEnvironmentProcessIdMessage
data.value: Use 'Environment.ProcessId' instead of 'Process.GetCurrentProcess().Id'

data.name: UseEnvironmentProcessIdTitle
data.value: Use 'Environment.ProcessId'

data.name: UseEnvironmentProcessIdFix
data.value: Use 'Environment.ProcessId'

data.value: Validate platform compatibility

data.name: PlatformCompatibilityDescription
data.value: Using platform dependent API on a component makes the code no longer work across all platforms.

data.name: AvoidStringBuilderPInvokeParametersMessage
